item.title: Dimiterscu Wine, Tofu, and 26 More Brilliant Little Resident Evil Requiem Details
item.content:encoded:
This article contains spoilers for Resident Evil Requiem.

Resident Evil Requiem finally sees the series return to Raccoon City, so it‚Äôll surprise no one that it‚Äôs campaign is loaded with Easter eggs and references to the past. From deep cuts referencing 1998‚Äôs Resident Evil 2, to nods to more modern games in the franchise, here are 28 brilliant little details we‚Äôve spotted in Resident Evil Requiem so far.

For veteran fans, the unquestionable highlight of Requiem is Leon‚Äôs return to the RPD. Well, its ruins ‚Äì it definitely didn‚Äôt look like this last time. As expected, the dilapidated department is packed with references to the past.

1. Before you enter the doors of the Raccoon City Police Department, you'll notice the streets around you feel very familiar. Look behind you, and you‚Äôll see the tanker that separated Leon and Claire, and then subsequently exploded, still in the exact same position it was 28 years prior.

2. Right next to the tanker is a building with ARUKAS written on it, which is a reference back to the original 1998 game, which in turn referenced Street Fighter Alpha 2‚Äôs Sakura. Arukas is Sakura spelt backwards. Perhaps surprisingly, that isn‚Äôt the only Street Fighter reference you can find, but there are a couple of steps before we get there.

Once Leon is finally reunited with the RPD, he‚Äôs flooded with memories of his traumatic experience.

3. In Resident Evil 2, just before you‚Äôre introduced to the Licker, you find a dead police officer with its jaw sliced almost completely off. 28 years later, that police officer (well, his skeleton) is still in that exact same position, now notably sans jaw.

4. Also still in the RPD are the remnants of all the strange puzzles Leon and Claire had to solve, frozen in time and covered in dust. The Lion statue puzzle in the main hall is declared by Leon to be the oddest of them all when he says, ‚ÄúThis puzzle was weird‚Äù.

5. A trip to RPD wouldn‚Äôt be complete without a snoop around the S.T.A.R.S office, and although you can find lots of cool details in there, such as Jill‚Äôs beret, it‚Äôs Barry‚Äôs scavenger hunt that‚Äôs the most fun.

After following the two clues, you‚Äôll find a hidden key for a locker. This key has the word Jojo written on it, and for those who don‚Äôt know, Jojo is a reference to the Japanese manga JoJo's Bizarre Adventure, which was also written on a locker in the original 1998 version of Resident Evil 2.

6. The Jojo key opens a locker that contains a whole host of goodies, including Barry‚Äôs gift of two tickets to the Raccoon City Zoo, a location that appears in the Resident Evil Outbreak series, which also happens to be the game our hero Grace‚Äôs mom, Alyssa, is from.

7. At the base of this locker, though, is a wealth of PS1 nostalgia, which includes boxed copies of the original Resident Evil, Street Fighter Alpha 2 and Mega-Man 8. There‚Äôs also a poster for Street Fighter Alpha and what looks to be a TEMU PS1 that looks more like a Sega Saturn than a classic PlayStation.

8. Later on, on the ground floor of the RPD, you can spot random appearances through the cracks in the wall of everyone‚Äôs favourite edible hero, Tofu, who was an unlockable playable character in the original Resident Evil 2. Tofu, beret and all, peeks out to say hello. And yes, if you‚Äôre quick enough, you can pop a shot at him to do some damage to his squishy consistency.

I‚Äôm not sure what the exact trigger is for Tofu, but it feels like it‚Äôs just after you pick up Barry‚Äôs To Do List, which also appears to be the trigger for the next detail.

9. Wesker‚Äôs desk drawer is now an infamous location in the history of Resident Evil 2. In the remake, it contains a weapon component; in the original, after hitting the action prompt 50 times, you were ‚Äúrewarded‚Äù with an inappropriate photo of Rebecca Chambers. In 2026, after looking at Barry‚Äôs to-do list, you‚Äôll find a note about a book called ‚ÄòMedicinal Benefit of Herbs‚Äô, showing that it‚Äôs been returned to the library by Wesker. Make your way over to the library to find this book, look inside, and once again you‚Äôll find the photo of Rebecca, with a note referring to her as ‚ÄúRising Rookie Rebecca‚Äù. RRR then happens to be the code for Wesker‚Äôs briefcase, in which you find a charm of his iconic sunglasses.

10. Once you‚Äôve left the RPD, make sure to head left, and you‚Äôll be able to revisit the parking garage, the location where Leon first met love interest/frenemy, Ada Wong. In here, you‚Äôll find a cute bear charm, the same one seen on the keys that Ada hands to Leon in Resident Evil 4.

11. In the RPD, you‚Äôll once again come face-to-face with Mr. X. But did you notice that Grace actually bumps into him, too? Well, not really, but the guy that she brushes against the streets of Wrenwood at the very start of the game sure does look like he‚Äôs wearing Mr.X's outfit‚Ä¶complete with the fedora hat he wears in the RE2 remake.

12. Like Tofu and Mr. X, there‚Äôs also another returning Resident Evil 2 legend, who, although never outright named, is quite clearly everyone‚Äôs favourite no-nonsense mercenary, Hunk. This unlockable character from the original Resident Evil 2 (and many games that came after) turns up as a boss in Requiem‚Äôs final act, and somewhat lives up to his legacy, with Leon declaring him to be a tough bastard after they duke it out to the death. RIP Hunk.

Resident Evil 2 isn‚Äôt the only game from the series referenced in Requiem, though, with the previous entry, Resident Evil Village, also getting a couple of nods.

13. Just after you reach the helipad, you enter a room full of items to examine. One of these is a wine bottle which has the name Dimiterscu written on it, clearly referring to everyone‚Äôs favourite goth mummy from Resident Evil Village. The bottle is labelled ‚ÄúSanguis Virginis‚Äù, which is the same wine used to solve a puzzle in Village‚Äôs castle location.

14. Later on, in Spencer‚Äôs study, you can see a picture of a lone woman with the letter M on it. This refers to Mother Miranda, the big bad of Resident Evil Village and (as we find out at the end of that game) Ozwell E. Spencer‚Äôs idol and inspiration.

15. One of Requiem‚Äôs big bads is Victor Gideon, who sports some significant jewellery. Look close and you can see a snake motif on his ring. The same snake motif is seen on Krauser‚Äôs knife in RE4.

16. Requiem also has a reference to the silliest of Resident Evil‚Äôs puzzles, with Grace pointing out the ludicrous systems of opening doors in these zombie-infested mansions. When inserting the Red Gem into a door at the Rhodes Hill Care Center, Grace rightly states, ‚ÄúHow do normal people get in here?‚Äù

17. But perhaps no door in Resident Evil is more iconic than the original game's loading screen animations between rooms, something that is referenced near the beginning of the game with a slow zoom on the door before the chainsaw-wielding Doctor attacks Leon.

That battle is complete chaos, with a host of cool interactions with the chainsaw. There are a couple of brilliant details you might miss, though.

18. The chainsaw is unwieldy at the best of times, spinning wildly when on the floor. If you manage to kill a zombie while they‚Äôre still holding it, the chainsaw will end up dragging the fallen flesh eaters along for the ride.

19. A zombie can also be impaled with a still-operational chainsaw, the revving blade protruding straight through their rib cage. Don‚Äôt let them get too close, though, because if they grab you, then they‚Äôll drive their chest with the chainsaw directly into yours.

20. It‚Äôs quite clear that many of the other zombies roaming the halls of the Rhodes Hill Care Center have their own personalities, but there are also medical records you can find that share their names and defining traits, with a personal favourite being Eileen Zimmerson, one of the singing zombies whose personality disorder is described as ‚Äúmain character syndrome‚Äù.

21. Meanwhile, the enormous mass grinding its way through the hallways who we know as ‚ÄúChunk‚Äù is actually called Thomas K. Jackson, and the version Leon takes on is called Timothy B. Jackson. So they‚Äôre actually brothers, both with irregular eating pattern disorders.

22. Interestingly, several zombies still retain traits from their mortal existence, like the cleaning zombie, who is super focused on scrubbing the blood out of the mirror. She will, however, also move locations to clean up the gore you create by killing other zombies.

23. Later on, when Grace and Emily meet Harry Reed, most would progress on with the story while Emily is safe in the helicopter. If you‚Äôre a psycho, though, Capcom has prepared custom dialogue for Harry should you, for some reason, decide to unload on the whirlybird.

24. Capcom has also layered subtle instructions into the environment when Leon first takes to the motorbike in Raccoon City, with a billboard appearing very early on that says ‚ÄúLearn to Steer‚Äù just after the player takes control.

25. Leon is a master with his equipment, as shown when using a flashlight with his handgun. When you go to reload, Leon will smoothly tuck the flashlight into his shoulder, making for a very slick and detailed animation.

26. Also interesting: when reloading, both Grace and Leon will retain the magazine if there are still rounds in it. If it‚Äôs empty, they‚Äôll discard it.

The final details are, at the time of writing this, part of an unsolved mystery, so answers might be out there by the time you watch this, but they‚Äôre super cool nonetheless.

27. After taking out the Tyrant, you‚Äôll notice a basketball court with a suspicious-looking head in the middle. Shuffle kick that head along until it goes through the hoop, and you‚Äôll get a new action prompt that tells you ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no time for playing around‚Äù. Instead of pushing forward to the orphanage, head back to Kendo‚Äôs gun shop, and you‚Äôll now find a prompt on a headless Toy Uncle bobblehead that reads ‚Äújust ignore A‚Äù. Our first theory was that this was a reference to the ending choice, since the first option (or "A" ending) isn‚Äôt the canon one, but we‚Äôve since stumbled on something else that might explain it further‚Ä¶

28. The final mystery is a doozy that we‚Äôve yet to solve, but here are the hidden clues we have so far. After your escape from The Girl in the elevator shaft, her arm will be severed and available to pick up. It didn‚Äôt appear to serve any purpose until we decided to run it through the analysis machine you use to upgrade your crafting recipes.

After solving this puzzle, you‚Äôre shown a black screen that says ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs Play‚Äô, and a sequence of letters: G,A,U, and C. Based on the prior clue, I think it‚Äôs safe to ignore A.

Hidden in the game are some clues to what these letters mean. In an hourglass you can find and rotate, U is revealed to be linked to the number 380,000. In Grace‚Äôs blood analysis report, C is 4.2 LY, and on the side of the blood analyser device, there‚Äôs a sticker that says G = 15,000,000.

What does all this mean? Well, our guess was that it‚Äôs the distance to the moon, sun, and nearest star, which also happens to be the sequence buttons for the puzzles in the Rhodes Hill Chronic Care Center. After using the G, U, C sequence and translating them into moon, sun, and star inputs for the machine, entering that code triggers a creepy laughter sound effect.

What does that mean? That‚Äôs where we‚Äôre stumped! Hopefully, you‚Äôll already have the answers and can drop it in the comments.

And that‚Äôs everything we‚Äôve spotted so far in Resident Evil Requiem. Did we miss any cool Easter eggs, or are there small gameplay details we missed? Let us know in the comments.

Dale Driver is an Associate Director of Video Programming at IGN. Be thoroughly bored by following him on Bluesky at @daledriver.bsky.social

item.title: Marathon Review So Far
item.content:encoded:
From ARC Raiders to Escape From Duckov, extraction shooters seem to be enjoying something of a renaissance right now, to the delight of shooter fans like myself. But of all the newcomers to that space, none have captured my attention more than Marathon since I first played its early alpha over a year ago. Even through some of Bungie‚Äôs recent lows, the idea of taking the high-stakes looting deathmatch that is an extraction shooter and combining it with the unparalleled shooting for which the studio is known has always been an awesome idea. Now, after playing Marathon for the better part of a day as it kicks off its server slam ahead of launch next week, that rad concept seems to have turned out about as well as I was hoping it would, with absolutely stellar gunplay, some interesting characters and lore, ands a a loot grind that‚Äôs made it hard to step away long enough to even write this initial review. It‚Äôs still way too early for me to say if any of this will have staying power all the way through my 100th run, but it‚Äôs left a very strong first impression.

Marathon - Gameplay Screenshots

I‚Äôve always had a difficult time describing exactly what makes a Bungie gun feel so damn good, but whatever it is, Marathon‚Äôs got it. Maybe it‚Äôs the deliberate musicality to weapons, like that crisp snap from a rifle report, the metallic clink of a trigger, or those amazing hollow thuds when you land a shot. Maybe it‚Äôs the way recoil feels rhythmic, with pulse rifles kicking like a heartbeat and handcannons bucking theatrically. Maybe it‚Äôs the way the world reacts to your shots, with shields crackling and splintering, and enemy NPCs staggering in place as you riddle them full of holes. Maybe it‚Äôs invisible qualities, like the almost perfectly tuned bullet magnetism and finessed projectile speeds, all working together to make you feel slightly better than you actually are. An old Bungie dev once told me that the secret to making a great shooter is in making four seconds of gameplay that feel perfect, then repeating those four seconds as many times as you can. I don‚Äôt know if this remains a guiding philosophy of the current team, but in any case, they really seem to have nailed just that.

As someone who adores PvP, one massively refreshing aspect of Marathon so far is how far it deviates from the group hug energy of ARC Raiders‚Äô PvE-friendly community. Don‚Äôt get me wrong, cooperating with other players can be a hell of a time, but one of the major drawbacks is that you don‚Äôt get to see the PvP shine when it rarely happens. In a game like Marathon, with Bungie‚Äôs legendary FPS chops on full display, I‚Äôd be pretty disappointed if PvP encounters were as rare as they‚Äôve become in ARC Raiders, because those gunfights are without question the best part of any match. The pressure of two teams squaring off in claustrophobic, dark hallways, as you try to outmaneuver one another makes for some of the most ten se encounters I‚Äôve ever had, and the loot reward you get for winning those firefights is worth the stress (after all, the best way to loot is to let someone else do it for you and take it from their cold, dead hands).

The mark of a great extraction shooter is that ‚Äúone more run‚Äù feeling, and a big part of that lies in how fun the long-term loot game is. That relies on both the badass weapons and gadgets you‚Äôll find, as well as the quest items you‚Äôre asked to collect if you want to unlock an upgrade or complete a mission you‚Äôve been given. In the early hours, I‚Äôve been completely glued to my screen, poring over dense menus and trees to figure out which map I‚Äôll need to play to complete this quest or loot that item, then going into battle with a specific set of objectives in mind ‚Äì only for it to all go to hell when I run into a rival gang and the shrapnel starts flying. I‚Äôm really impressed by how fast the progression feels so far, and even during failed runs, I‚Äôve seemed to make at least some kind of progress despite losing valuable loot along the way.

Obviously, acquiring a new weapon on the battlefield, like a long-distance rifle capable of one-shotting poorly-armored characters, then customizing said weapon with neat mods you‚Äôve found along the way feels awesome. But there‚Äôs also little ways you can progress, like unlocking the ability to buy a larger backpack if you‚Äôve lost all of yours in the battlefield, or gaining access to better shields in the store instead of having to rely purely on your ability to loot them out in the world. So far I‚Äôve never felt like any of the progress lost on failed runs has hindered my desire to immediately jump back in, even when a particularly devastating loss left me with only white-rarity weapons.

TieGuyTravis' Favorite Extraction Shooters

For those who like risking it all on loot that's well worth it, these are your best bets.

See All

It‚Äôs also been great to see the story play a larger role than I expected it to. After each mission, I‚Äôve had some new faction to meet, a few quick lines of dialogue thrown my way, or some lore unlock for me to read, and I find myself really interested in learning more about this world and its inhabitants. I haven‚Äôt had nearly enough time to actually dive in here, as it can be tough to find reading time when your crewmates are waiting on you to launch the next match, but the vibe of these cutscenes and the spooky cyberpunk aesthetic is so damn interesting. I‚Äôm eager to know more. Here‚Äôs hoping the pace of lore continues as strongly as the first day has, and that it actually leads to some kind of payoff, since Bungie notably isn‚Äôt always great at this.

The Server Slam alone doesn‚Äôt paint a full picture, but it has got me excited to play more as we approach the full launch next week. I‚Äôll be diving deep into every aspect of Marathon and be back with a final review once I‚Äôve fully put it through its paces.

item.title: Pok√©mon FireRed & LeafGreen Switch Update Censors Naughty And Offensive Names
item.content:encoded:
Watch your language, trainers

One of the joys for many trainers during the earlier generations of Pok√©mon was giving the main character and their rival a rude or downright inappropriate name. In the Switch eShop versions of Pok√©mon FireRed & LeafGreen, it seems there have been some updates to this.

As reported by Kotaku, you'll either have to get really creative now, or there's a good chance the game will override whatever you've input and instead give you a generic name. Here's a sample of some of the words that won't fly:

"Kotaku has verified that some words, such as ‚Äúd**k,‚Äù ‚Äúp***y,‚Äù ‚Äús**t,‚Äù and even the f-slur are replaced by names like ‚ÄúGary‚Äù or ‚ÄúJanne.‚Äù This doesn‚Äôt seem to extend to some milder words, however, as ‚Äúhell‚Äù and ‚Äúdamn‚Äù were not replaced."

This update appears to impact Pok√©mon names as well. One obvious theory suggests the update is to prevent users from flooding social media with screenshots and footage containing offensive language. This also wouldn't be the best look, as Pok√©mon is meant to be a family-friendly experience for all ages.

As many trainers have highlighted, this confirms these classic Game Boy Advance releases have actually been edited for this special release. There have also been some other updates...

What are your thoughts about this? Let us know in the comments.

item.title: Kinki Spiritual Affairs Bureau coming to Switch 2 in 2026
item.content:encoded:
• Switch 2

Currently available for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, and PC.

Publisher AMATA Games and developer Noto Muteki will release horror action game Kinki Spiritual Affairs Bureau for Switch 2 in 2026, the companies announced.

Kinki Spiritual Affairs Bureau first launched for PC via Steam on October 4, 2024, followed by PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series on July 15, 2025.

Here is an overview of the game, via AMATA Games:

About

Kinki Spiritual Affairs Bureau is a Japanese-style horror third-person shooter game where you can fight back against the spirits.

This game is not a classic Japanese horror game where you can‚Äôt fight back against the spirits. In Kinki Spiritual Affairs Bureau, you‚Äôre just as much of a threat as the spirits themselves!

Gameplay Mechanics

  • The main gameplay consists of unarmed combat, gun shooting, and stealth action.
  • There are a total of 10 stages to clear.
  • The game includes plenty of story-driven cutscenes.
  • Four difficulty settings are available, allowing players from beginners to advanced to enjoy the game repeatedly.
  • The button configuration for game controllers can be freely changed, enabling personalized play.
  • As a feature unique to the Nintendo Switch 2 version, the game now supports mouse-like pointer controls using the Joy-Con 2.

item.title: GameStop Attempting to Break Mario Cosplay Gathering Record
item.content:encoded:
It‚Äôs a we, Mario!

March 10 has become Mario Day (Mar 10) for many gamers. This year, a New York City GameStop is to celebrate the day by attempting to break a record for the largest gathering of people dressed as Mario. The current record for the largest gathering of people dressed as Mario is 230 participants. This was set on August 18, 2010, in Chifeng City, Inner Mongolia, China.

It will be an entire Mario-themed event. There will be prizes and many photo ops. The best Mario cosplayer will receive a free Nintendo Switch 2. All who participate will also receive $5 in bonus store credit to use on any item in the store. You‚Äôre free to come dressed as Luigi, but you won‚Äôt get the store credit.

Qualifications for the costume are simple. All you need is a red shirt, blue overalls, a red hat, and a mustache.

Mario Is Still Celebrating His 40th Anniversary

Through April, with the release of the Super Mario Galaxy Movie, Mario continues to celebrate his 40th anniversary. As part of the anniversary, Nintendo has released Mario Tennis Fever. There‚Äôs also an upcoming Yoshi game, Yoshi and the Mysterious Book. However, most are wondering when the next 3D Mario experience will be released.

It has been almost 9 years since Nintendo released Super Mario Odyssey on the original Nintendo Switch. This is easily the longest timeframe between brand-new 3D Mario releases. Nintendo released a port of Super Mario 3D World on the Nintendo Switch, which included a secondary mode in Bowser‚Äôs Fury. However, they have not released a full 3D Mario game since 2017.

With the latest Mario movie celebrating the legacy of one of the best-reviewed 3D Mario games of all time, many are dying to get back to the Mushroom Kingdom in a brand new experience. For now, maybe you can go to New York City and dress up like Mario and hope of winning a free Nintendo Switch 2 so that you‚Äôll be ready whenever that new game does come.

item.title: Call of Duty Warzone Adjusts Killstreaks in Season 2 Patch
item.content:encoded:
Raven Software has revealed patch notes for the latest Call of Duty: Warzone Season 2 update. The patch includes an update to Killstreaks in multiple modes and other bug fixes.

Regarding Killstreaks, several updates have been made. They have adjusted the spawn rates of Killstreaks in loot. Resurgence modes have received a 50% reduction from Supply boxes and a 25% reduction from ground loot. This adjustment also counts for Ranked Play. Battle Royale modes have received a 10% reduction in Killstreaks overall.

They‚Äôve also made specific adjustments to Precision Airstrikes, Napalm Strikes, Cluster Strikes, and Bunker Busters. The radius for Killstreak call-ins has gone down to 150 meters. It was originally 255 meters. They‚Äôve also adjusted the limit from three to two. Additionally, they‚Äôve made a change to where only one type of Killstreak is allowed in any given radius.

‚ÄúIndividually, you can deploy one Killstreak of a specific type every 20 seconds. Your squad is limited to one active Killstreak of that type as well. Once used, this allows opponents a window to retaliate. We will continue monitoring Killstreak usage and performance across all modes and make adjustments as needed,‚Äù the notes state.

Additional Bug Fixes in the Latest Call of Duty: Warzone Patch

Additional bug fixes include a fix to an issue that prevented players from properly progressing the ‚ÄúAbsolute Zero‚Äù mastery camo challenge for the NX Ravager. Also, an issue that allowed players to fall through maps in certain areas has been fixed.

item.title: Pok√©mon Winds and Waves' Two Dressed Up Pikachu Have Ridiculous Official Names
item.content:encoded:
And yet, I love them.

Today, Pok√©mon Winds and Pok√©mon Waves were announced during a Pok√©mon Presents, showing off a new region, three new starter Pok√©mon, new player characters, a lot of returning Pok√©mon, and two overdressed Pikachus with the most ridiculous names I've ever heard.

The trailer that aired today began with a cinematic showing a regular Pikachu flipping through a scrapbook of its adventures in different regions throughout the different Pokemon games, before stepping away from the book to answer a knock at the door. When the door opens, two other Pikachu are waiting outside dressed and ready for vacation. One, a male Pikachu (based on the tail shape) is wearing a floral polo shirt, sunglasses, and a big white sunhat with a flower. The other, a female Pika, has on a blue and pink floral sundress and a blue baseball cap also with a flower. Her cheeks are pink instead of red.

These are, apparently, Mr. Windychu and Ms. Wavychu, and no, I'm not making those names up. These names are from the official Pok√©mon website.

Apart from their names and their official artwork, there isn't much info about who these guys are. They're clearly each coded to one of the two versions of the game, and notably, their hats correspond with the hats the protagonist trainers wear in their respective versions.

item.title: We Build LEGO Pok√©mon Pikachu: A Shockingly Fun Build
item.content:encoded:
LEGO and Pok√©mon were my childhood (well, those and TMNT, but that‚Äôs for another time). I grew up building everything from simple cars and unrealistic houses to whatever amalgamation my creative mind could imagine. Never, as a kid, did I expect to see a fully licensed Pok√©mon set like the one we have now.

When I was a child, Pok√©mon was a game that, even now 30 years later, still has its claws in me with no sign of letting up. My younger siblings and I spent hours as kids, sitting with our Link Cables and GameBoys, trading Pok√©mon back and forth while we restarted one of our games enough times so we could each start with all three starter Pok√©mon. I knew I was hooked after spending an afternoon at my grandfather's house manually typing out my own Pok√©mon guide listing every Pok√©mon, their evolution levels, and what level they learned each move.

Pikachu and Pok√© Ball - LEGO Pokemon

There is no Pok√©mon more iconic to the franchise than Pikachu, and while this set's first images weren‚Äôt as impressive as I‚Äôd hoped, I've changed my mind after building it and seeing it up close. As I gaze at it sitting on my shelf surrounded by other Pok√©mon plushes, statues, and numerous other Pok√©mon collectibles, I have to admit that it looks great! Is it perfect? No, but man, it‚Äôs a very welcome addition to my collection.

With Pok√©mon celebrating its 30th anniversary, it‚Äôs the perfect time to build this latest collaboration and go back to the series' roots, even though Pikachu wouldn‚Äôt be a selectable starter until Pok√©mon Yellow‚Äôs 1997/1998 release. LEGO provided IGN with a review set for a test build, and I was excited and fortunate enough to be the one to put it together. This 2,050-piece build took me around six hours to complete, which was long enough to revisit Pok√©mon: The First Movie (that big final moment still brings tears to my eyes), Detective Pikachu, and a couple of other Pok√©mon movies that were available to stream.

In the earlier steps, I was confused as to why our favorite little yellow mouse had so many vibrant pinks, teals, and other non-Pikachu-specific colors while building. However, as I finished the steps and his torso began to take shape, I realized all the additional colors would be hidden in the final build, and were there to make piecing together the inside easier.

Lego Pikachu Build Slideshow

It showed me how far LEGO has come in reducing complications and making larger builds faster to complete. I couldn‚Äôt help but smile after hitting major milestones in the build, and had the biggest one of them all when I settled Pikachu into his final resting position surrounded by the plastic lightning, making his action pose even more dynamic.

The biggest drawback to this LEGO Pikachu set is the $199.99 price tag; it's not much larger (size-wise) than its more affordable counterpart, Eevee, and it doesn‚Äôt feel as epic as the much more expensive Kanto starters set. Pikachu‚Äôs set comes with 16 bags. The first nine build the electric mouse #25 (National Pok√©dex) himself, while the remaining seven build his Poke Ball and the base to attach him to. The instruction manual is the same as the other Pok√©mon sets and comes with a Pok√©dex entry for Pikachu, as well as a look back on his history with the franchise, which was fun to remind myself of how far he and this franchise have come. Steps are well organized throughout the building process, and while the first few steps may look nothing like Pikachu, they quickly take shape as you move into the middle steps.

Similar to the Eevee build, as you progress, you will assemble sections, leaving small pockets open to eventually attach its articulable arms, legs, ears, and tail. Pikachu‚Äôs build starts with the internal portions of his torso, neck, and head, then adds the external rounded pieces to give him his iconic look. His lightning bolt-shaped tail and base were the highlights of the build for me, and they look great in LEGO form, accentuating Pikachu‚Äôs design. These steps were the simplest parts of the build, but they were also the most satisfying for me. Pikachu also features a few fun, swappable parts that can easily be adjusted for a new look. Swapping a hinge inside the pokeball converts it from open to closed. Pikachu can stand on his own or attach to his slanted stand (my preference), and you can swap the endcap pieces on Pikachu‚Äôs tail, swapping between heart-shaped (female) and pointed (male).

While not perfect, Pikachu‚Äôs feet are surprisingly pose-able to help with balancing him. Just take precautions during the build, because mine did take a tumble or two. His arms, however, are limited to vertical mobility and are prone to detaching if you try to adjust them too far outside that range. The good news is they are extremely easy to reattach should that occur, as it did to me a few times while rotating to attach new pieces.

His ears are also fantastic for articulation, as they can be rotated and angled freely, allowing you to quickly change his look. I only wish the set had a few more alternate pieces, like his mouth, to change his expression. There were only a few steps throughout the build process that gave me some trouble, and one of them was attaching the single round pieces to the center of another round piece. This made sense as one of the last words that comes to mind for me when I hear the word LEGO is round, which made these complications understandable.

The final portion of most steps is adorning Pikachu with pieces that help distinguish him from any other pile of yellow bricks. Thankfully, Pikachu‚Äôs eyes and mouth are printed on pieces, so no worries about ruining a set with a slightly misplaced sticker or anything of that nature. The eyes and mouth are both singular pieces to attach while his cheeks are a simple combination of pieces to give them their rounded appearance.

After completing Pikachu himself, the last things to build are his Pok√© Ball and lightning bolt-shaped stand, which made up the last seven bags of pieces. Though that's 40% of the bags, it's also filled with lots of larger flat pieces and was the quickest part of the build. This was great because I built it in two sittings, making getting to the finish line easier and all the more enjoyable.

What generation of Pokemon Starters should get a Lego set next?

Pikachu may not be my favorite Pok√©mon (Bulbasaur, you know, I had to include him in here at least once), but it was still an incredibly fun build and a wonderful addition to my collection. Each step after the first few clearly showcases what you're building, from the memorable stripes on its back to its lightning-bolt-shaped tail. For those who love Pikachu, I think this is an easy recommendation if you have the cash to spare. The pictures and marketing don‚Äôt really do this one justice; it's one of those sets that look much better in person.

item.title: Bloomberg: Bluepoint Games pitched a Bloodborne remake, but was turned down
item.content:encoded:
• PlayStation

FromSoftware was reportedly against the idea.

Bluepoint Games, the Demon‚Äôs Souls and Shadow of the Colossus remakes studio closed by Sony Interactive Entertainment last week, pitched a Bloodborne remake in early 2025 that was turned down, according to a Bloomberg report by Jason Schreier.

The studio was reportedly told that while the numbers made sense, FromSoftware, the studio behind the original Bloodborne, did not want to see it happen.

Sony Interactive Entertainment‚Äôs former head of independent games as well as former Worldwide Studios president Shuhei Yoshida theorized in an interview with Kinda Funny in 2025 that the reason the company has not done anything with Bloodborne was out of respect for FromSoftware president Hidetaka Miyazaki, who directed Bloodborne.

‚ÄúI left first-party, so I don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going on,‚Äù Yoshida said at the time. ‚ÄúBut my theory is, because I remember Miyazaki-san really really loved Bloodborne, what he created‚ÄîI think he‚Äôs interested [in remaking the game], but he‚Äôs so successful and so busy that he cannot do it himself. But he doesn‚Äôt want anyone else to touch it. So that‚Äôs my theory. And the PlayStation team would respect his wishes.‚Äù

The original Demon‚Äôs Souls was also developed by FromSoftware. Miyazaki, speaking to Edge magazine in 2022 (via VGC), said that while he had not played the remake by Bluepoint Games, he was happy to see it renewed for a new generation‚Äîsupporting Yoshida‚Äôs theory that Bloodborne may be a special case.

‚ÄúAs you say, I was not directly involved in it, and I haven‚Äôt actually played the Demon‚Äôs remake,‚Äù Miyazaki said at the time. ‚ÄúBut this is because I just don‚Äôt enjoy playing the games that I‚Äôve made in the past. It brings up a lot of old emotions, a lot of old memories, and this gets a little bit overwhelming, and it doesn‚Äôt feel like playing any more. So I have not played the Demon‚Äôs remake, but I am very glad to see it get this fresh look, these brand-new current-gen graphics.

‚ÄúIt was an old game, so to see it get remade in this way and have new players playing it was obviously something that made me very happy.

‚ÄúIt was a rough game back in the day, with a relatively rough development, so I was anxious that new players would not enjoy it in that same way. That was a cause of concern for me when it was re-released but, you know, in the end, I‚Äôm just happy to see the reaction and happy to see people enjoying it.

‚ÄúOne thing that was really fun was seeing [Bluepoint Games] come up with things we didn‚Äôt consider and to approach certain elements of the game its visuals and its mechanics in a way that we either couldn‚Äôt or didn‚Äôt back in the day. So to see them researching and applying these new thought processes and new techniques, this was something that was really exciting and interesting for me.‚Äù

Unrelated to Bluepoint Games, Brandon Sheffield, director at Demonschool developer Necrosoft Games, said his studio also pitched a Bloodborne-related project to Sony Interactive Entertainment.

‚ÄúI could find you 10 companies that have pitched a Bloodborne sequel, spinoff, or remake, including my own,‚Äù Sheffield said on Bluesky. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just not going to happen unless [FromSoftware] decides they want to do it.‚Äù

Bluepoint‚Äôs Closure

The Bloodborne pitch is a small part in a larger report surrounding Bluepoint Games‚Äô closure. According to Bloomberg, following its acquisition by Sony Interactive Entertainment, Bluepoint Games continued its work assisting Santa Monica Studio on God of War Ragnarok.

After 2022, the studio began work on a live-service game set in the God of War universe, in which the character Atreus falls into Hades. A loose idea was for players to control different versions or aspects of Atreus as they battled through Greek hell, and to include some form of cooperative gameplay and ongoing support, but much of the game‚Äôs design was still in flux.

Bluepoint Games struggled to develop a live-service game, being a small team mostly skilled in art and engineering rather than design. Some Bluepoint Games staff wanted to work on a traditional action game rather than a live-service project.

After several years of struggling development, even with help from Santa Monica Studio, Sony Interactive Entertainment canceled the God of War live-service project in January 2025.

It was around then that, in searching for its next project, Bluepoint Games pitched a remake of Bloodborne. After that was turned down, it spent some time pitching an updated version of Shadow of the Colossus, the PlayStation 2 game it had previously remade in 2018, but that was also turned down. It also pitched other studios under the Sony Interactive Entertainment umbrella about developing new projects in other franchises, such as a spin-off of Ghost of Tsushima, but nothing was greenlit.

By February 2026, Bluepoint Games had gone more than a year without securing a new project. After Sony announced plans on February 12 to remake the original God of War trilogy without Bluepoint Games‚Äô involvement, some employees at the studio grew uneasy. One week later, it was announced that the studio was shutting down.

According to people familiar with Sony Interactive Entertainment‚Äôs thinking, the company no longer believed Bluepoint Games was equipped to make its own game and was unable to find a partnership that made sense.

Recently, as Bluepoint Games‚Äô former staff look for jobs‚Äîincluding opportunities to apply for positions at other studios within Sony Interactive Entertainment‚Äî other companies were making phone calls to see if there might be a way to salvage the studio, according to people familiar with the situation, as unlikely as the prospect may be.

Back in the day, sure, we were all about the gorily OTT RE chainsaw controller for GameCube, but two decades on? We're a little more sophisticated than we used to be, perhaps. We don't need blood splatter over every prong of our pad, and this new one could sit on the side quite comfortably without alarming pets or family members.

Let's take a closer look at those little details, courtesy of our lovely video chap Alex, shall we? First, some close-ups, then a handful of moody shots that may well have been snapped in a Raccoon City warehouse! Or possibly Alex's garage:

Tasty, no? Itchy, right?...

If you're interested in seeing how it compares to the regular Pro Controller colour-wise (it is a little different), check out Alex's short below, and our review of the non-Evil version.
